reviewText: I really like Sir
date: you are being hunted" and I think it's a very special game that deserves your attention
recommended:
but there are things in this game that stings me in a very uncomfortable way and that may scare away players.

Let's start with the things I liked:

Open world  - First time I jumped into the game I had no idea where to go. North? West? East? South? Stay in Central? In that specific moment of time
hoursPlayed:
I felt the game was drenching me with choices and oppertunities. I like those moments very much and they get rarer each time I play.

Random generation  - This is a part of the game I also enjoyed. When you start a new game you'll have the option to change what biome the islands will have (Except for the center island. It's always rural.) and the amount of enemies you'll face.

The thrill of being hunted  - Since this is a game about stealth
voteText: it will punish you for not being stealthy enough and it does so by letting the robots run after you and try to kill you if you've been spotted. Robots will also alert other robots nearby of your presence
helpfulPercent:
which makes the game alot tougher. I have gotten myself hunted and killed a number of times and sometimes a special type of robot will hide in thick patches of forest and wait until you get close enough to them.

And now the things I didn't like:

Graphics and textures  - After about 27 hours of running around on islands looking for fragments I have noticed certain graphical errors such as bricks you're able to see through and houses that looks like tall buildings that just sank into the ground until they hit something.
The textures makes me cringe a little
votesHelpful: especially one of the ground textures that reminds me of Call of Duty's digital camouflage but with fitting colours instead of the traditional black
votesTotal:
white and grey. Another example of my despise towards some of the textures is in the castle biome. I enjoy walking up in castletowers and looking down on robots with my binoculars but I always notice that the inside of the towers have the exact same texture as the outside which I find to be a little annoying.

The goal of the game  - Collect 17 pieces from the islands. Bring them back to spawn. Win the game. This entire process is quite boring and it prevents me from continuing to play due to all of the motivation that was drained when acquiring just a few of these fragments.
An example of my train-of-thought when returning fragments:
"Alright! Returned 3 in a go and I have ... 9 fragments left?!? *sigh*"
"Screw it! I'll deal with this later."

The gunplay  - I have to admit that the firearms and weapons lacks authenticity in both sound
votesFunny:
look and feeling. The guns have a very basic design and the reload animations are basically non-existent. The revolver's cylinder doesn't pop out of its place so new bullets can get in and double-barreled hunting shotguns doesn't break in the middle. It just tilts itself in a way that makes me think that a hole opens and new shells glide in without me seeing it.
The game compensates this by making ammunition so rare that it is nearly impossible to really observe and analyze how a certain weapon looks and feels like.

Survival  - Survival in games is generally a value that the player has. The player needs to find objects that reduces this value from reaching zero. Survival in this game is exactly what I just described. You walk around and look inside buildings in order to find something to "eat". No sound is played to amplify the feeling of eating. You just "use" the item
commentsCount: it disappears and your hunger has a slightly higher value.\n\nBuildings  - Houses and buildings is a common sight in "Sir
column16: you are being hunted". It can get people pretty excited when they can imagine themselfs walking into an uninhabited shelter
column17: desperately looking ammunition
column18: food or tools. Or just seeking refuge. That doesn't apply to this game. Houses in "Sir
column19: you are being hunted" have the same function as a chest or a crate.\nYou open it up
column20: take what you need then leave. This will make houses in this game useless if you ever need to take cover in them. I personally wish I could get inside houses when I'm being chased. Getting cornered when hiding behind a giant rektangle is one of the worst ways to die
column22:
this doesn't apply to the aforementioned castletowers.

TL;DR

I like this game. You might not like it. Buy it on a sale. Preferably 75% off. That's what I did."

reviewText:
If you've found yourself let down by walking simulators due to the lack of tension/stuff to do but were still attracted to the genre you'll love this.  Procedurally generated landscapes, an awesome retro-future-dystopian aesthetic and great stealth gameplay await you here.

I adored Dear Esther, Eidolon was brilliant and Proteus was fun - this is similar in the exploration of an unknown landscape - but here be dragons (well robots).

I'm not a huge FPS player, I have finished Portal, finished Fallout 3, left HL2 at that boring car level after Ravensholme and that's about it.  I need a good narrative to get me playing.  I found it here.

This game is fantastic, the level of tension is unparralelled, in Dishonored, I know if I get seen I can probably fight my way out, in this, I'm ♥♥♥♥ed if I'm found.  This sort of urgency/agency is rare.

Varied and interesting enemies, great terrain, excellent narration.  Five out of ♥♥♥♥ing four!

hoursPlayed:
I felt the game was drenching me with choices and oppertunities. I like those moments very much and they get rarer each time I play.

Random generation  - This is a part of the game I also enjoyed. When you start a new game you'll have the option to change what biome the islands will have (Except for the center island. It's always rural.) and the amount of enemies you'll face.

The thrill of being hunted  - Since this is a game about stealth
voteText: it will punish you for not being stealthy enough and it does so by letting the robots run after you and try to kill you if you've been spotted. Robots will also alert other robots nearby of your presence
helpfulPercent:
which makes the game alot tougher. I have gotten myself hunted and killed a number of times and sometimes a special type of robot will hide in thick patches of forest and wait until you get close enough to them.

And now the things I didn't like:

Graphics and textures  - After about 27 hours of running around on islands looking for fragments I have noticed certain graphical errors such as bricks you're able to see through and houses that looks like tall buildings that just sank into the ground until they hit something.
The textures makes me cringe a little
votesHelpful: especially one of the ground textures that reminds me of Call of Duty's digital camouflage but with fitting colours instead of the traditional black
votesTotal:
white and grey. Another example of my despise towards some of the textures is in the castle biome. I enjoy walking up in castletowers and looking down on robots with my binoculars but I always notice that the inside of the towers have the exact same texture as the outside which I find to be a little annoying.

The goal of the game  - Collect 17 pieces from the islands. Bring them back to spawn. Win the game. This entire process is quite boring and it prevents me from continuing to play due to all of the motivation that was drained when acquiring just a few of these fragments.
An example of my train-of-thought when returning fragments:
"Alright! Returned 3 in a go and I have ... 9 fragments left?!? *sigh*"
"Screw it! I'll deal with this later."

The gunplay  - I have to admit that the firearms and weapons lacks authenticity in both sound
votesFunny:
look and feeling. The guns have a very basic design and the reload animations are basically non-existent. The revolver's cylinder doesn't pop out of its place so new bullets can get in and double-barreled hunting shotguns doesn't break in the middle. It just tilts itself in a way that makes me think that a hole opens and new shells glide in without me seeing it.
The game compensates this by making ammunition so rare that it is nearly impossible to really observe and analyze how a certain weapon looks and feels like.

Survival  - Survival in games is generally a value that the player has. The player needs to find objects that reduces this value from reaching zero. Survival in this game is exactly what I just described. You walk around and look inside buildings in order to find something to "eat". No sound is played to amplify the feeling of eating. You just "use" the item
commentsCount: it disappears and your hunger has a slightly higher value.\n\nBuildings  - Houses and buildings is a common sight in "Sir
column16: you are being hunted". It can get people pretty excited when they can imagine themselfs walking into an uninhabited shelter
column17: desperately looking ammunition
column18: food or tools. Or just seeking refuge. That doesn't apply to this game. Houses in "Sir
column19: you are being hunted" have the same function as a chest or a crate.\nYou open it up
column20: take what you need then leave. This will make houses in this game useless if you ever need to take cover in them. I personally wish I could get inside houses when I'm being chased. Getting cornered when hiding behind a giant rektangle is one of the worst ways to die
column22:
this doesn't apply to the aforementioned castletowers.

TL;DR

I like this game. You might not like it. Buy it on a sale. Preferably 75% off. That's what I did."

reviewText:
One of the best things about this game is its variablilty.

No matter which way you go at it, you are bound to be challenged and intrigued. While the inventory at your disposal is somewhat limited, there are many ways to use it. Whether you would rather distract the enemy or simply gun them down, there is a viable method for you!

The procedurally generated landscape and buildings ensure surprises around every corner, no matter how many times you create a new file.

The suspense and style of this game will never tire, as the fear of encroaching enemy forces permeates all.

I would strongly recommend this game to stealth lovers, action gamers, and puzzlers alike. The multiplayer mode is excellent- I just wish more people played it!

One problem I had was that my cursor intermittently disappeared, making inventory navigation quite difficult.

I found great enjoyment in this game, despite its graphical simplicity. Here is a general summary of my experience.

Step 1: Buy Sir You are Being Hunted"

Step 2: Start new file. How hard can this be?

Step 3: Enter world. See the robots. Laugh.

Step 4: Run at robots. Kill them all.

Step 5: Get shot. Get shot again. Bleed out. Cry.

Step 6: Respawn. Look for food.

Step 7: Suddenly
date:
Airship. Cry myself to sleep.

Step 8: Respawn. See robots. Run in fear. Hide.

Step 9: Find cool sh*t. Lots of guns. Overconfidence levels rise.

Step 10: Shoot everything. Pull dank trickshots.

Step 11: Steal fragments.

Step 12: Start fire. Run away.

Step 13: Walking in field- get mauled by attack dog. Cry self to sleep.

Step 14: Hear abnormal noises. Landowner ensues. Try to kill. Fail. Die.

Step 15: Scarecrow. Run. Get caught. Shot.

Step 16: Love the Game.

Once again
recommended: I strongly recommend this game to all. Be sure to get it- you won't regret it!"

reviewText: Sir, You Are Being Hunted looked like an interesting game so I picked it up while on sale. Don't get me wrong it is a decently interesting game but nothing seems to specifically stand out. The story is failry straight forward and allows technically an infinite replayability, though, personally one play through is enough for me. SYABH seems to be more or less an outdated looking stealth FPS that we see a lot these days that doesn't offer much of anything new. Also it does not really include any aspects of humor, which was disapointing. The only thing I really enjoyed playing this was the ability to customize the map to my liking, dictating what scenery is located where (though this was really basic and honestly nothing special). The fact that looting a house" is like opening a chest in skyrim. You can't even go indoors (it just opens up a menu screen)! No hiding in the houses from baloon riding robotic sirs for me! (which by the way
date:
was one of the few clever ideas to include in the game). Lots of negative reviews say it is fun for the first hour but then gets boring - this is true. Many others say the game is not very rewarding - this is also true.

+Interesting idea
+Technically infinite replayability with major map differences
+Map generation and customization
+Steam Trading Cards
-Outdated graphics
-Cannot enter buildings
-Overpriced
-Unrewarding gameplay

Do I recommend this game? Sure
recommended: if it's 5$ on sale I recommend grabbing it and trying it for yourself!"

reviewText:
This is definitely a FPS that is for those with an acquired taste for this kind of game.

There are a lot of good concepts in the game. A randomy generated world, an interesting survival-esque style of gameplay, and an odd setting in general to keep you on your toes.

However, the gameplay feels sluggish. Also, limited inventory space is something that is seldom fun in any game: but it's even less so when your main objective markers (that are literally scattered around the world) have to be carried back to the center of the world so often due to small inventory space. It's backtracking that artifically increases the length and difficulty of the game.

It's not a bad game. And depending on your tastes, you may end up liking it a lot. But it's certinly not a game that can appeal to the masses.

5/10 Mediocre""

reviewText:
I bought this game expecting something cool and suspenseful and replayable, but what I got was a half-baked product that was so low-quality that I couldn't believe that the developers would release something so unfinished under the tag of 'Early-development'.

The first thing you'll notice in this game is the complete lack of challenge. The bots are completely easy to avoid, and hunger isn't really ever a struggle or challenge for the player because you can find food everywhere in the towns. The only part of the game that comes close to difficult is when the air-balloons fly around and spot you with their spotlight.

Second, there's absolutely nothing to do in this game. Every game has some sort of direction it wants players to go in. Even DayZ has the loosely defined goal of 'getting tons of cool stuff, making a helicopter, and killing other players'. But in Sir, You Are Being Hunted, there is nothing that the player needs to accomplish. The developers /knew/ this would be a problem in an open-world, single-player game like this, but do you know how they tried to fix it? They added a goal where players need to follow these little shiny 'wisp' looking things to crystal shards so that they can go to another island.

As a player, I'm left thinking, 'why do I want to even do that'? What's my motivation to collect the shards? The next island is gonna look pretty much the same, and it isn't going to be any harder to clear than the last. The game itself is a chore. A chore I paid like $15 for, and not even a fun one like pulling lint out of an AC filter.

Don't buy this game. I bought it a year ago expecting the money to help the developers work even faster on the game and make a great final product, but now the game is pretty much the same as it was when I bought it.

Oh, and one final note. The voice-work in this game is pathetic. It's some guy with a painfully-fake British accent talking into a headphone microphone. You can even hear it 'pop' when he says 'p' syllables because they didn't even have a professional microphone with a pop guard. It makes me angry to think where the 'early-development' money PLUS the kickstarter money went.

reviewText: Honestly, just boring. Run around island looking for smoke that indicates scavenger hunt pieces. Either chuck a bottle to distract or just kill the couple guards at the piece. Collect it. Repat until island is clear. Run back to start, deposit pieces. Repeat with the other islands. The various enemies really aren't that interesting and are easily avoided. If you do get spotted, you can just outrun things until they fall far enough behind. There's no real sense of fear at any point. The classes are pointless because it's so easy to find plenty of items that what you start with hardly matters. The only items that are really useful to have as early as possible are any kind of gun and the map. I did one playthrough, beat it in ~2h with one death 5 mins in while I didn't have a gun yet. I saw no reason to drag myself through another game.

reviewText:
This game isn't terrible but it could use a lot more work, like most Early Access games.  Good base plan: survive in open world where your only real goal is to escape.  I've always wanted to resident evil game like that, where you randomly find lickers and tyrants in the city and can run or fight.  Back to topic...  Good plan, lazy execution.

First, you can't go inside of buildings.  Just one question... Why?  In an area full of evil robots (or any enemies searching for you) crouching in the 2nd story window of a house and shooting down or throwing a bomb would feel great!  I understand this game is about being sneaky and hiding if you can, but that's even more reason to be able to go in building.  The general world doesn't have too great of hiding spots.  You need buildings to hide in and jump to and from just to get around anywhere that has more than one robot.

Second, any robot with a gun deals so much you are lucky to survive and patch yourself from the first shot.  Then, even if you do survive, you can't (to my knowledge) put bandages on your hotkey bar.  So, you can't instant patch yourself, meaning you have to pause and do it while they are still chasing you or else you will bleed out in about 10 seconds.  God forbid you get hit in a field or an area with nowhere great to hide, because you will get shot and killed while trying to bandage yourself.

Next, minor complaint: I do wish it was true open world.  I mean that the islands were all loaded with a render distance enabled.  Having to teleport from boat dock to boat dock is a little lame feeling.  I want the moment of running from robots, hopping on a boat and sailing out while ducking in to the boat and barely escaping in to the sea.  Then having the excitement of finding a new island and trying to find a safe place to dock.

I'm pretty good about going on for a really long time when reviewing games, so I'll cut it here, but I just have to say: Good start.  Great idea with the possible escape to try and give the open world genre some feeling of meaning, unlike games like minecraft which, while very fun with friends, can get dull fast when you realize all you are looking forward to is fighting a very laggy dragon that clips through blocks, to get an egg that does nothing.  But if this game wants to be remembered it needs to open it's doors (literally) and brouden it's scopes.  Also, not sure if this is a thing, but it would be cool if you could use hotair balloons you shoot down.  Patch them, etc.  Then be able to fly anywhere with them (again requiring a true open world).

I would honestly recommend this game to anyone who thinks they have the balls or the brains to try it, but take my word for it, You Never Will.

reviewText:
This game is an interesting Indie title that has not recieved the attention i think it deserves. It is a Survival/adventure game, but could be classified as survival/horror. The game puts you in the shoes of an English lord who is being(you guessed it)hunted. Hunted by what? oh, just robots...thats right, the game pits you against robotic hunting dogs, hunters of all shapes and sizes as well as air balloons. The game features a good stealth system, as well as providing tension and such. It may only be in alpha, but it is already a great game.

+Well devoloped stealth system.
+A large enviroment to explore.
+Already great even in alpha.

-Needs work on glitches and bugs.
-Could use more enviromental biomes.
-More survival aspects would be nice.

Overall, i would reccomend this game to those seeking a good survival game.

reviewText: I love this game! The whole concept is amazing and i'm glad I purchased it in the alpha stage because i'm completely devoted to seeing it through. The only problem is the robots. Not that i'm not thrilled to have tweed-wearing robots as the enemies, but sometimes I play and its too much trouble for me to try to go into a town to try and loot some houses. It seems that the robots in a town are so closely linked so that if you set off one it alerts all of the other robots on the island. Well, im exaggerating a little, but the robots are very alert to the others. When the robots shoot you, the blood loss is incredible. I know thats what rags are for but you can bleed out in a matter of seconds so they're not the bet choice sometimes. Maybe add a syringe for health? Anyways, I like this game a lot, but there are some problems. Thumbs up!

reviewText:
LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT. Is so creepy, you have to hide as best as you can. i prefer to hide at night because I can't see too well then.

Now professionally......
I quite enjoy the game. When I first tried out the game, it was relatively simple. Squires in towns that you can't let see you looting houses otherwise they get irritable, poachers in the woods that force you to be wary of bear traps, scarcrows that work like living weeping angels that don't kill you but scream like crazy, a blimp, a seamonster, and normal hunting robots with their temporary bear trap dogs. Now, It has branched out a fair bit. Now there are very speedy horsmen who run you over with the force of a steampunkish floating car and knock you flat in doing so, a castle biome, the landowner with his cane & freaky horn noises & knocking you flat on your back where his 2 pet hounds finish you off and or trap you, and much fewer fragments to find beefore you win. As a side note, something weird happened yesterday in the game for me while I was offline but that can wait until later. Anywho, all this christmas pudding and brandy and such, is simply delicious. For me, this is a game of eats, sweets, meats, hunting, running, hiding, ambushing, trapping, eating bad food, hurting, eating all sorts of random mushrooms you find, shooting, hacking, sneaking, stealing, escaping, and definitely more but I don't know what.
Also, I propose 2 new things to add to the game. Fishing, and either digging or undrground tunnels with exceptionally well hidden entrances. the tunnels would probably be in the mountain biome. I know that you are working on the multiplayer thing right now probably, but I mean when you are done with that I think it might be a good idea. Maybe adding a mine biome? There is or was such a thing as mines on small islands.

reviewText:
There's lots of promise in this game. It is playable in its present state (August 2013) but clearly there is refinement to come.

I am generally not a fan of playing games in an early access state. I will withhold a proper recommendation until a later date. But as it stands, it’s interesting. I had no game crashes.

…I’m not convinced that it’s going to be *fun* though, or a game that makes me want to play it again after successfully completing it once. Looking forward to seeing how this game turns out.

reviewText: I was initially somewhat anxious about the art style in the game, as nothing in particular jumped out at me. I'm still not wild about the UI, as the flat graphics aren't incredibly appealing (It's still in beta, so take with recommended salt) but the overall visuals have completely won me over. The game immediately impresses both the haunting dread of being stalked and mercilessly hunted, but also a fantastic sense of the dark and drearily consuming English countryside. I can almost feel the wet, muddy chill of the air just sitting at my desk.\n\nThe tone is perfect so far, and I am enjoying it greatly - though the anxiety it causes me may spell why I have so few hours under my belt as of yet.

reviewText: This is a game you cannot help but fall in love with.  If you were one of those people where as a kid loved to play hide and go seek with your friends, then this is the perfect game for you.  It totally brings back that cold sweat excitement and heavy breathlessness you get while hiding and watching the seeker pass by.  This game boils over with nostalgia.  And as for the game play; it does take some patience, and you have to be in the right mood for it.  But the way the gun mechanics work, and the way the robots prance around tirelessly searching for you; it's all just so perfect. And... IT'S STEAM PUNK!!! (as you should be able to see) The moment I saw this game I just had to buy it.  I adore steam punk.  I ADORE THIS GAME!  If you haven't bought it, and you're like me, don't hesitate.  Get it.

reviewText: At first i did not like this game, but quickly i grew to love it. Initially the bad graphics and the 'fetch all the peices across the map' game mechanic turned me off. But after playing for a few hours i became incredibly absorbed. At the beginning and most likely for the first few hours you play this game as you learn the mechanics , the dastardly british robots seem pathetic , they move around in small groups of 2-3  and can be dispatched with ease from a few blows with an axe. DO NOT LET THIS FOOL YOU as you collect more of the fragments needed to complete the game the amount of robots hunting you increases exponentially. Near the end of the game by god do you feel hunted as you crouch in a thick field of wheat and pray that you will not be found as the sounds of countless robots walking mere metres from you chills your blood , you know that if they had thought to bring there matallic hunting dogs with them or if they had run into you 5 minutes back when you were traversing an open field then you would not be alive to pray this prayer. As the amount of robots hunting you increases so to do does the variety. Each one is vastly different and you must relearn many of the lessons you have learnt before. Being able to increase the amount of robots and the times when they appear is a very fun feature as you can vastly increase an already difficult game. I bought sir you are being hunted 80 percent off in a sale i have had it for two days and have already put 14 hours into it (the time it says i have played is alot less than the actual time do to most of my playtime being offline) . I predict that i will invest much more time into it , especially seeing as they plan to add multiplayer in the future. I suggest that you dont buy this game full price but wait for a sale.

reviewText:
The standard control scheme, when you start the game first, is utterly garbage, and if you don't modify the game, I joke you not, this game is unplayable. The standard controls are some kind of design created for an absolute masochist, with four hands, and three keyboards. You will not have any idea at all of the scope of the game, the usefulness of certain items, their value, the availability of resources, until at least half an hour into a game. If you have the patience of a Saint, this is the game for you. Forget walking Simulator, this is Crouch-walking simulator. Moving at the speed of a particularly slothly snail, hiding in cover as the robots hunting you pass you by, because there is absolutely no reason to kill enemies in this game. You will rarely, if ever, pick up any more ammunition for your weapony, that is if you find any weaponry at all. I got an axe at one point, but in order to use it, you have to sneak up on your foe... who walks faster than you can crawl. Enemies tend to stand still for approximately the amount of time it takes between you dropping a glass in a restaurant and the entire place going quiet, and will kill you in the amount of time it takes for someone to clap or whistle in congradulations for dropping said glass, if you so much as stray an inch out of their exact 180 mark.

This was one of the biggest let downs I have ever encountered, as I've been following it since this game was even announced, and the delivery thus far has been plain insulting for the price demanded.

If you really, really, really want to play this game, don't let me stop you.

reviewText:
I run through the bushes, and a root trips me. I turn, landing on my back; holding onto my axe tighter; preparing to swing.

The robot looks down at me, pulling down on the trigger, but slowly. I have time to take action. I swing, and the robots head drops on the floor. I kick it away, look around, and notice the air ballon moving towards me, and the even more lethal threat below it.

The Landowner.

reviewText:
Have you ever wanted to lead your friends into battle against robots by sounding the charge by poorly playing your rusty trumpet?

Dont answer, I know this is everyone's dream.

Look no further! This game will take care of all of your needs. Want to hide around the corner from a squad of robot hunters while sipping lukewarm tea? Now you can! Strike fear into the hearts of your enemies by equipping everyone in your game with a trumpet and stroll through the streets, sounding off the war horn, warning all the robots of their incoming demise.

I remember it like it was yesterday, *BUUUUUUUURRRRRRRR* *BURRRRRRRRRRRRRR* *BUUUUURRRRRRR* We took down countless robots trying to gather the pieces of the teleporter all while keeping our spirits up with the lively trumpet of freedom. Living off of the food we scrounged together, mainly wisky and tea, we kept our strenght at maximum. We all had our designated weapons of choice. I was the shotgun specialist with an axe and no regard for the law. Near the end of our struggle to escape, we came across an ammo supply shortage during our biggest battle yet. Thankfully we never lost our morale due to the constant *BUUUUUUUURRRRRRRRRR* our trumpeter played, both to keep us from retreating from the robot scum and to strike fear into their hearts. We started to take casualties due to having to make the fight more upclose and personal, but we never stopped the trumpet. The trumpet is a symbol of freedom, of hope. The last one of us starts to make a break for it towards our safe zone, littered with traps and stocked full of supplies. Not once did he let up on that trumpet. At this point it was just so that the robots wouldnt lose track of him into our turf. The trumpeter makes it into the ruins of a large building surrounded by small walls, filled with bear traps. This is the last stand. We need to let the world know. He climbs to the top of the pile of rubble in the center of the ruins and... *BUUUUrrrrrRRRrRRrRRrrRRrRRrrRrrRRrrRR*. Robots stepping on traps left and right. Never once letting go of that trumpet. Never once giving up hope. Not once will we let up on the trumpet. Not once will we stop taunting them with our freedom. The last trap is sprung. A robot dog dashes up the rubble and tackles the trumpeter off of the top.

The battle is over, but we've left our mark.

10/10 would trumpet again.

reviewText:
You crawl around a barron field, looking for smoking rocks.  They're usually surrounded by robots with guns, so you need to lure them away first, which isn't hard.  Then you grab the rock and put it in another rock.  Do that enough times and the game ends.

That's pretty much it.  There's a few items, most of which are not actually useful.  There are some houses, but you can't enter them, they're just scenery.  There's a few types of enemies but the strategy with all of them is the same.

My friends and I were incredibly excited to play this with each other, given our love of stealth and roguelike games.  We were all very disappointed, and don't understand the hype for this game.  It still feels like very, very early access.

reviewText:
I realize that there's a HUGE score of strange, maladjusted gamers these days, who just LOVE extreemly hard, post doomsday, waste 1,000s of hours gathering B.S. to keep playing, so you can gather stuff for many thousands of hours to come...

ONE class starts with weapons, yes one out of like 5+ custom to choose from, then if you do happen to agro some robots early on... you can die when you run out of bullets, even though NONE of the bullets you shot them with hurt them even at all that I could tell. (This is offline it wasn't a cheater or anything online).

I saw this game in the Steam store, & though: [Hmmmm nice art style, steampunkish, this game claims to be humerous... MAYBE this game isn't like those other million, boring as watching grass grow, post-______ games, & it's on sale, oh well let's give it a try!]

I spent I think $1.90 on this game, & I feel like I got ripped off! Buyer beware, if you actually have reflexes faster then a turtle, & expect your games' guns to aim/fire/etc. quickly, & effectively... then stay FAR away from this steaming pile of brown stuff, BUT if you thouroughly enjoy REALLY bad games, & want to spend more time hunting down easy resources like some mindless drone, then actually playing a game... this may be your cup of Joe! Seriously when I cannot kill one robot by shooting it with 10 rifle, & 6 handgun shots POINT BLANK, then the game is idiotic at best.

reviewText:
I was honestly looking forward to this game. I got it on sale during the steam summer sale. I wasn't over-hyped about it, but I was looking forward to it. I love a good survival game. This isn't it though.

It has a good concept though. A survival game with smart ai that are trying to hunt you. The bad part is the environment for me. For starters, you can't go in buildings. That wouldn't be so bad if the actual terrain was interesting. Looting pretty much amounts to running up to the doors of houses and hiting the action button.

There's only like 10 items in the game that are actually useful, which is sad. That makes the game feel even shallower than it already does with the lack of interiors. I was bored with the game about an  hour in. There just wasn't a whole lot that made me want to keep playing.

I wholeheartedly reccomend this title.

reviewText: I love the core concept behind this game.  The victorian era robots, the abandoned country side, the stealth and survival mechanics, the procedurally generated environments; those all sound wonderful.  Hell, my first couple of hours were very enjoyable.  The environments feel organic, the enemies are scary (at first), and exploring the first couple of islands is an enjoyable experience.  Unfortunately, it is very repetative, and any potential for deep gameplay disperses as soon as one realizes how easy it is to abuse very simple mechanics.  The stealth is uninspired, and the survival mechanics are ruined by an over-abundance of food.  It's odd for a game with procedurally generated terrain and item drops to have so little replay value.\n\nA huge dissapointment.

reviewText:
Stealth and survival - definitely. I enjoy the tension provided by sneaking around the hunters, sometimes within touching distance, and the decision making. This often involves deciding whether I should seek necessary vittles or go for that tantalisingly close fragment. After all, it is guarded by only 2 robots...

Guns are available, but this isn't an FPS. There isn't enough ammo to start with, and gunfire brings in nearby hunters. Numerous robots of varying scariness and abilities are on the hunt for you and at times it's like being on Argyle Street on Xmas Eve due to the number of determined bodies in your field of view.

This is a straightforward game that provides suspense, thrills and chases. The light humour is welcome too. All entertaining and that's what I was wanting when I bought this as an Alpha. A finished product worth the money and not buggy? Yes, and multiplayer is being added next year.

Graphics+ The graphics are quite well, And it's still alpha,

-----------------------------------------Overall Rating: 9.0-------------------------------------------------
Overall it's a great game. And i can't wait to see how much it progresses.

reviewText: In this particular gem, you play as an Englishman who's been transported to a quintet of dreary islands by a machine. Robots of every social class roam the isles and are busy hunting you as their own little fox so they can kill you. In order to survive, you have to hunt wild game, rummage through the various (thoroughly de-human-fied and therefore abandoned) buildings, and track down pieces of the machine that sent you to the robot-ruled hell. Lower class, upper class, it doesn't matter which they're from, each and every breed of robot has its own unique method of coursing you. This is not a game where you blast through hordes of enemies and stand tall with a crass cigar between your teeth. You have to take careful stock of each and every potential encounter and perform a cost-benefit analysis, as even two or three robots can annihilate you with a single volley of their shotguns and rifles. Combine this with a limited inventory space, and you have a pleasant challenge. The islands are also randomly generated, which makes each playthrough unique. You can modify the generator to a wonderful degree, producing a ton of island variations. If you want to be both scared and amused, I would suggest getting this game right away.

reviewText: So there I was, somewhere on a random island. Looked like Britain, though, I couldn't be sure. I had only my shotgun, a trombone, and a couple bags of chocolate biscuts. I was running low on tea. I needed to get to that house... but they were right there.... But luckily, I had set a trap earlier. I played my trombone as loud as I could, making insane sounds that blasted through the night. SNAP! It had been caught. With a single shot, I took the hunter down. He had some ammo on him, but nothing more other than his broken gun. I had proceeded to the house... quietly... carefully, like some sort of RPG thief whose stats were high in stealth... but not enough... WHAM! Right then, one of their damned blood hounds had pounced on me, I fought for my life, hoping it wouldn't bite my face off. I had shot down the hound, but then, it was already over; another one had caught me behind my back and blasted me through my chest. As blood leaked out, slowly and painfully, I tried to wrap up the wound with some rags, but from another shot from his gun, I was already dead. Damn robots. Good game for a price of $20.

reviewText:
HNNNNNNGGGGG. This game is a survival fps, a mix of STALKER and Don't Starve. The genre it self is already my GOTY. I am recommending this as of Aug 22, 2013. Its currently in alpha so don't say I didn't warn you.

You are a human. You are stuck in this dark/grim looking world with robots hunting you (you are an alien to them).  Your mission is to collect pieces of these magic rocks to power up this mechine that takes you back home. Along the way, you must stay alive and don't starve. You must search houses or robots you killed for supplies to stay alive till get back to the real world.

Gameplay: Its an FPS; find gun, shoot robots, don't starve, SURVIVE. You start out with nothing and you need to search for your 1st weapon. Weapons ranges from currently that I see in game are, axes, bear traps, revolver, 2 barrel shotty and a hunting rifle. Guns seems inaccurate so you do need to conserve ammo ALOT. Robots consists or dogs, normal huntsman in various cloths (seen in title art), fat town mayor guy and a flying ballonist spotter with floodlights that alarm nearby robots. To stay healthy you need to eat things, some things are bad for you like rotten food but you can cook some game. Currently you can't hunt game yourself so you have to find them in houses/robots and cook them at bonfire. Stealth is a BIG part of your survival. You are not a bullet sponge and you will be killed because currently it feels like the robots have aim/wall hacks. But you do regen health as long as you're not starving. Inventory management is also a big part of your survival. Its a tetris based bag and you have limited space where you can store things. You have to choose weather to pick up food vs ammo vs gun vs space to pick up those magic rock fragments to stay alive in the world. Also there is no storage chests so you have to be a hobo and scavage things or store them in nearby houses and hope you know where to refind it.

For comment on art style of this game just youtube, I can't really describe it to you. Its not realistic, its kind of a grim/dark cartoony thing but its VERY fitting to what they have going on.

Overall, I LOVE THE GAME and this can and will be my GOTY when it release. If you want to try it out BE WARNED: ITS IN ALPHA, updates will change gameplay. What I heard is dev is thinking about adding mulitplayer (so DayZ with robot as zombies with guns...HNNNNNNNNNNGGGG) and new content like trappers with traps that set up and wait for you to get caught and kill you.

TL;DR - FPS survival, great gameplay, my GOTY nomination, still in alpha so be warned. >If I didn't like it so much then why did I just write all this review? ITS A ♥♥♥♥ING GREAT GAME.

Get out of here Stalker, you are being hunted...

reviewText:
HNNNNNNGGGGG. This game is a survival fps, a mix of STALKER and Don't Starve. The genre it self is already my GOTY. I am recommending this as of Aug 22, 2013. Its currently in alpha so don't say I didn't warn you.

You are a human. You are stuck in this dark/grim looking world with robots hunting you (you are an alien to them).  Your mission is to collect pieces of these magic rocks to power up this mechine that takes you back home. Along the way, you must stay alive and don't starve. You must search houses or robots you killed for supplies to stay alive till get back to the real world.

Gameplay: Its an FPS; find gun, shoot robots, don't starve, SURVIVE. You start out with nothing and you need to search for your 1st weapon. Weapons ranges from currently that I see in game are, axes, bear traps, revolver, 2 barrel shotty and a hunting rifle. Guns seems inaccurate so you do need to conserve ammo ALOT. Robots consists or dogs, normal huntsman in various cloths (seen in title art), fat town mayor guy and a flying ballonist spotter with floodlights that alarm nearby robots. To stay healthy you need to eat things, some things are bad for you like rotten food but you can cook some game. Currently you can't hunt game yourself so you have to find them in houses/robots and cook them at bonfire. Stealth is a BIG part of your survival. You are not a bullet sponge and you will be killed because currently it feels like the robots have aim/wall hacks. But you do regen health as long as you're not starving. Inventory management is also a big part of your survival. Its a tetris based bag and you have limited space where you can store things. You have to choose weather to pick up food vs ammo vs gun vs space to pick up those magic rock fragments to stay alive in the world. Also there is no storage chests so you have to be a hobo and scavage things or store them in nearby houses and hope you know where to refind it.

For comment on art style of this game just youtube, I can't really describe it to you. Its not realistic, its kind of a grim/dark cartoony thing but its VERY fitting to what they have going on.

Overall, I LOVE THE GAME and this can and will be my GOTY when it release. If you want to try it out BE WARNED: ITS IN ALPHA, updates will change gameplay. What I heard is dev is thinking about adding mulitplayer (so DayZ with robot as zombies with guns...HNNNNNNNNNNGGGG) and new content like trappers with traps that set up and wait for you to get caught and kill you.

TL;DR - FPS survival, great gameplay, my GOTY nomination, still in alpha so be warned. >If I didn't like it so much then why did I just write all this review? ITS A ♥♥♥♥ING GREAT GAME.

Get out of here Stalker, you are being hunted...

reviewText:
The best English Countryside simulator I have played to date.

Now that I've played this game, I have lost my desire to visit England and go wandering in the heath. (No, not because of the killer robots, silly -- that constant drizzle of rain is just depressing.)

I die a lot when I play this game. Usually because a robot shot me a second time while I was desprately rummaging through my inventory looking for something to stop the copious bleeding from the first gunshot wound.

You will spend a lot of your time in this game hiding in the long grass, desperately hoping the balloon robot won't find you.

Game offers gender options! Can be either a sir or madam that is being hunted.

Great game. Sometimes I play again. Then I bleed to death, alone on the windswept heath and have to go do something less depressing.

reviewText:
You're going to die. You're going to bleed to death, you're going to starve to death, you're going to be shot with shotguns, or blugeoned with giant robo-canes, or gnawed on by vicious robo-hounds, or spmething equally unfair.

That's sort of the point though. This game isn't at all fair, and it makes that the central theme. You, Sir (or Madam) have been unceremoniously deposited in an alternate dimension. In Britain. Your interdimensional whatever has exploded all over five islands, and in order to get home, you needto find the smoking remains and cram them in to a conveniently sized hole in a magic rock.

Also, there are a lot of robots, and no people.

Robots have a pretty good idea what you want, and despite some clearly worded letters to the contrary they aren't inclined to give it to you. They'll do a pretty decent job of patrolling, on foot, in baloons, with robo-hounds, and they'll make a habit of frequenting the places where you find things you need to not starve to death or die from being mauled by robots.

As you retrieve the pieces of your gizmo, the robot hunt will intensify, adding new types of robots to the hunt and increasing their number.

Luckily, you have the opportunity to save your progress at the aformentioned magic stones, or at the boats that carry you between islands. You should do that, because you're probably going to die once or twice.

Aside from weaponry (which is pretty scarce) there are plenty of insteresting gizmos to spice up your experience including bear traps, fire, trombones, alarm clocks, toy trains, hallucinogenic mushrooms, and a slow of other useful or just fun to find stuff to help, hinder, or amuse you along the way.

I highly reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys a decent stealth experience, roguelikes, or those who like survival games like DayZ or Nether but don't appreciate the PvP focus found there.

reviewText: I rememeber being so psyched when i first read an article on this game for Sir, You Are Being Hunted. British country side where robots hunt you down and you must survive? sold to the man for 20 bucks in the black suit. Ultimatly what it comes down to is running, shooting, drinking and dying. Now you maybe asking me, is it fun? Its ok, but its certainly nothing thats hasn't been done before, they promised to add co-op (which is one of the reasons why i bought it) but it never was implemented. Games running on the Unity engine can look really good (Guns of Icarus Online) but this isn't one of those. I have yet to re-install it after all this time and guess what. i am not at a loss at all. My two regrets of this game was buying it and convincing one of my friends to buy it as well. There are PLENTY of survival crafting games out there (the market is practically bursting at the seams) and more so PLENTY better than this one. Save yourself the tears and bitter self-resentment and just don't purchase it.

reviewText: Sir, You Are Being Hunted совмещает удивительные и абсолютно дикие элементы. Шутер от первого лица и стелс являются основной ставкой геймплея. Большую часть времени вы занимаетесь тем, что ищете осколки артефакта, разбросанные случайным образом по случайно сгенерированому миру. Если доходит до стычек с роботами, то приходится использовать пушки (дробовики, ружья, снайперские винтовки, пистолеты) и вовлекать себя в совершенно неадекватные интеллигентные перестрелки. Дело в том, что враги двигаются по необычной, даже хаотичной, траектории, которую сложно предугадать и описать словами. В любой момент раненый оппонент может устроить тактическое бегство 'задом' или вовсе начать отстреливать своих же сородичей. Мне кажется, что так они изъявляют несогласие с чрезмерной шумностью братьев по металлу, потому что неподобающее поведение недопустимо

reviewText:
You have 2 choices: Be devious, sneaky, and never get caught by using gadgets to distract the bots. This is the smart option you should do if you want to finish the game.
Be ruthless. Murder every robot you see. A lot of fun, even though you WILL die a lot. This game makes most fights fair, but sometimes they become one sided. Never in your favor however. There will either be no advantage, or the robots have it.

I suggest you get this game. Its amazing. Good for both stealth lovers, and for those who like a good fight.

reviewText: Sir, You Are Being Hunted совмещает удивительные и абсолютно дикие элементы. Шутер от первого лица и стелс являются основной ставкой геймплея. Большую часть времени вы занимаетесь тем, что ищете осколки артефакта, разбросанные случайным образом по случайно сгенерированому миру. Если доходит до стычек с роботами, то приходится использовать пушки (дробовики, ружья, снайперские винтовки, пистолеты) и вовлекать себя в совершенно неадекватные интеллигентные перестрелки. Дело в том, что враги двигаются по необычной, даже хаотичной, траектории, которую сложно предугадать и описать словами. В любой момент раненый оппонент может устроить тактическое бегство 'задом' или вовсе начать отстреливать своих же сородичей. Мне кажется, что так они изъявляют несогласие с чрезмерной шумностью братьев по металлу, потому что неподобающее поведение недопустимо

reviewText: if you like being hunted and having to stay alive this is a great game for it!!! i not sure what makes it so much fun exactly but maybe its the intense suspension of are you being watched, should i fight off the robots or avoid them, are there robots in this town and if how many, and of course you have a commentator that its really awesome and is also helpful! another fun thing is getting to choose what starting kit you have so you are not forced to start with nothing but instead with what play style you want. if you are a fan of games like DayZ or stealth games this is a great game for you and i would recommend getting it, and dont worry you action FPS fans you can go guns blazing if you want to but i would recommend against it for it will burn through your ammo leaving you questioning how much longer you can survive!\n\nOverall i would give this game a 9/10 because even though it is now a full game it is lacking features that i would like to see added like multiplayer (but dont worry devs said it is to come) its still a great game and would highly recommend getting it!!!

reviewText:
Great concept.
But that's it.
I'd expect this to be a beta or even an alpha or be sold for $5.

A short synopsis: (don't worry about spoilers because there's little to no plot to spoil)
You pick a character, generate a group of five islands, and then begin. With a smug sounding narrator telling you some basic information every so often, you quickly pick up the basics of gameplay of movement, looting, and stealth.
And then thats it.
You just wander around an island searching for rocks to put in a bigger rock while avoiding robots that are hunting you.
Sure there are letters and little tea sets you can look at but they serve no purpose. After a certain point the narrator even says that he'll be gone and you're on your own for the rest of the game. No crafting, no special items or gamemodes that can only be obtained with certain actions. The only real difficulty in this game is the lack of inventory space. Robots can be easily avoided by walking in a large circle around them with the use of some alarm clocks.

I'd love to see a crafting system or more variety in the game, being able to pick what type of island each one is and what starting items you recieve is hardly variety. Seriously, just look at Don't Starve for ideas to expand gameplay.

I'd rate this a 2/5: this is either an alpha or overpriced

reviewText:
This game is about STEALTH and PATIENCE. It is NOT about going fast, or about shooting things, not at all.

If you enjoy travelling through randomised foggy rural islands, looking around for robot patrols and sneaking around them, the game is probably for you.

There is not much else to do in the game other than exploring and sneaking, but the landscapes are enjoyable and the robots do offer good challenge. You are not very likely to re-play the game unless you are really into rainy british landscapes, and the first playthrough is probably around 5-7 hours depending on your playstyle (and luck).

These hours do offer you a nice amount of leisurely exploration, thoughtful planning, suspenseful hiding and occasional hasty escapes. So, in my opinion the game deserves to be played. Maybe it doesnt deserve its full price, but this game is certainly worth trying.

reviewText: I played this on Linux and it did fairly well on the open source ATI drivers. Sir, You Are Being Hunted isn't a bad game at all, it does get a little repetitive but it really doesn't take away from the game play much. This game can be fun but very frustrating and I recommend playing this through at least once.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game. I know that line is clichéd at this point on steam reviews, but I really do, I usually love sneaking and survival games but Sir comes off as really tedious with its gameplay.

I suppose the real thing holding me back on Sir (it's going to make me sound like a casual noob but) is its difficulty. The robots are way too smart and it makes just about every strategy I try guaranteed to fail at least five times. Not the mention the fact that robots have a tendency to always gather around lootable buildings and never leave. I’m always forced to do some sort of trickery that, like I mentioned before, never seems to work on them. Later, I figured that the fastest strategy actually just involved running through and looting as fast as I can since the robots were always too smart for any of my tricks to reliably work efficiently.

Even ignoring all of that, the game’s charm wears off after about an hour of play, and what you’re left with is poorly designed sneaking sections that encourage exploiting to get through them and a combat system obviously designed to make you NOT want to use it.

11/10 –IGN.

reviewText:
Ok, so I played only half an hour of this game, and my impression is quite negative.

Why I played only half an hour? Because I wasn't even able to equip a weapon from the inventory (using both controller or keyboard/mouse). The game doesn't even have a tutorial, and nowhere it is explained, and it is not intuitive. So, after half an hour of frustration (I've played a lot of games, and never it happened to me to not even be able to equip a weapon!!) I quit.

In that half an hour I've also noticed very poor graphics quality. No, I know that is the art-style (and I kinda like it), I mean other things, like the grass billboards for example. If you look at the grass, you immediately realize it's 2D graphic file that is there to represent grass. I am a novice hobbyst Unity developer and even I know it can be done better. And the opening scene is made of static hand painted images that are so badly painted that I think they were made by a 14 years old art school student.

Overall, this game feels like a nice idea but poorly realized. I wanted to support and indie developer, but the indie developer must also support its customers. 3/10

reviewText:
I can't really recommend this yet.  The AI badly needs rebalancing, as does the combat in general.  I'm fine with weapons that aren't hitscan pixel-point accurate murder machines, but it's incredibly common to miss while iron sighting at ranges where even a blind geriatric could successfully score a hit.

The spawn placement of the artifacts sometimes is a giant middle finger as well.

Great concept, just still very clearly alpha quality.  Recommendation will probably change to a yes once there's more functionality and features implemented.

reviewText:
This game was on my wishlist for a long time, then it went on sale.  This really seemed up my alley--turns out that was mostly the (misleading) trailer.  I played through a few hours of mild disappointment, thinking I would just beat it and be done.  I had cleared 3 of 5 islands at this point, and had quickly come to expect nothing but more of the same monotonous slog of gameplay from beginning to end.

So I go to the West island and... my boat dock procedurally generated right into a sheer cliff's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  No matter, I shrug it off, as I just finished the mountain island and learned you can jump up about any embankment.  At the top of this one was one of the Mysterious Fragments, and some robuts wandering about.  HOWEVER, I must have been wearing a stovepipe tophat I was unaware of, as one of them saw me, behind some thick grass hanging off the edge of a cliff.  After I use my last marshmellow ammo on them, I sigh and reload.  Walking up the dock to bang my head against this, not the first nor last samey, mind-numbing obstacle in this game, a bundle of those robot arms that sprout from water shoot up THROUGH THE DOCK.  I decide not to take any evasive action, and the next keys I press are Alt and F4, followed by Delete Local Content.  I can't think of a single game that's done this to me, or that I did to it in return.  And that was just the straw that broke the camel.

If you are sick of the Tedious Inventory Management trend lately (of course they don't show that in the trailer), and aren't keen on imprecise stealth gameplay in a large smear of mostly empty wasteland, don't pick this up.  I wish I could get my money back.

reviewText: How could a game about british evil robots be boring, I don't know, it's a hard task to achieve and yet somehow that's what happened. I had such high hopes for this one, but I couldn't even finish it. The graphics were basic, the Sirs... well, the robots left me alone for a few hours while I wandered around the moors enjoying a walking simulator. There wasn't much to explore, you couldn't even enter the buildings. And when the evil robots started appearing... they just shot me from far away and that was it. No witty banter. No feeling of dark menace.\n\nIf someday I get to build my own army of classy, murdering robots, they will be more engaging, I promise.
